image.altText: Several fire trucks at the scene of a factory blaze.

items.synopsis: Dozens of firefighters have extinguished a major blaze that was burning across several industrial sites in Adelaide's south, sending thick smoke over the surrounding area.

title.children: Factory fire at three Adelaide industrial sites could leave multi-million dollar damage bill

image.altText: A man in a cap and glasses.

items.synopsis: Alan Leslie Graham was 79 at the time he was last seen in April 2016 at Angepena Station during a prospecting trip to SA's far north, and the state's coroner is now trying to piece together his final movements from witness testimonies.

title.children: Shoe sole and abandoned van among clues in outback disappearance of gold prospector

image.altText: Jason De Ieso was murdered in late 2012

items.synopsis: Seven out of eight men charged over the ambush killing of an innocent man in an Adelaide workshop more than a decade ago have been found guilty of murder.

title.children: Jury finds seven men guilty over shooting that killed accidental victim in 'escalating' bikie feud

image.altText: A young woman wearing a coordinated crochet set sits on a beach buggy

items.synopsis: Ahuva Maizel last spoke to her daughter early on Saturday. It was a brief phone call that has led to an unbearable wait for the family, who fear the 21-year-old has been kidnapped by Hamas militants.

title.children: Adi was dancing in the desert with friends. When Hamas advanced, she made one phone call

image.altText: Placard reads Aboriginal Sovereignty Never Ceded

items.synopsis: It’s become a well-used rallying cry by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people at marches and events and the term "sovereignty" has been brought up a lot throughout this referendum debate but there’s more to this term than you might realise – let's unpack it.

title.children: Have you heard the chant 'sovereignty never ceded'? Do you know what it means?

image.altText: A man underwater in full commercial diving gear, holding a chainsaw.

items.synopsis: Underwater chainsawing, welding and oxy-arc cutting are not skills on many people's radars. But they can be a gateway to a new career, a commercial diving instructor says.

title.children: Commerical dive training isn't 'swimming around looking at fish.' There's power tools and work to be done

image.altText: A man looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Aboriginal people are considering what the Voice might mean for them, and if they want it at all. The ABC visited several regional communities in Queensland and listened. Here's what they had to say.

title.children: Fred has 'lost a lot of white friends' in the lead up to the referendum. He hopes they can reconcile their differences

image.altText: A grid of three images of lidia thorpe speaking outside, and two men one wearing a white shirt and the other a camouflage hat

items.synopsis: Two notorious Australian Neo-Nazis are exposed as the likely architects of a menacing video in which a masked man denigrates Indigenous senator Lidia Thorpe before burning the Aboriginal flag.

title.children: A hidden timestamp on a 'menacing' Neo-Nazi video aimed at Lidia Thorpe indicates who the likely architects are

image.altText: Chinese flags near the logo Evergrande Centre in Shanghai, China, on September 24, 2021.

items.synopsis: Australia's biggest trading partner is facing its biggest economic slowdown in decades, and the Reserve Bank has warned that stress in China's economy will be felt across the world — including here in Australia.

title.children: How a 'sharp deterioration' in China's property market could affect housing affordability in Australia

image.altText: A young girl with long curly hair, wearing a broad-brimmed hat and cuddling a lizard, looks to the left of the camera.

items.synopsis: First inspired by the Black Lives Matter movement, the young First Nations trailblazer wants to preserve her culture and language for generations to come.

title.children: Penelope made her first film when she was six, now she's sharing her Indigenous culture on YouTube

image.altText: Elska Mia with her clear harp sits on backstage steps. She wears a glittery dress, pink lipstick and blue boots.

items.synopsis: Elska kept a dark chapter of her life hidden for years. Through her music, she's finally been able to tell that story.

title.children: How art has given me the freedom to share my sexual assault story for the first time

image.altText: A woman wearing a black wrist watch and grey nail polish measures her waist with a red and white measuring tape

items.synopsis: Like most weight loss programs, the OMAD diet makes bold promises — and comes with risks, writes Nick Fuller.

title.children: Bruce Springsteen might be a fan but in the long run the OMAD diet is unsustainable

image.altText: US President Joe Biden, in a suit and tie, speaks at a podium gesturing with his hands. Kamala Harris and a US flag stand behind

items.synopsis: Death tolls are rising in Israel and Gaza, as the US prepares to send its top diplomat to Israel to show its support and offer further assistance.

title.children: Biden calls Hamas attack 'sheer evil', as death tolls rise in Israel and Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Tim Callanan Representatives of the Australian Jewish and Palestinian communities have condemned anti-Semitic chants reported to have been shouted at pro-Palestinian demonstrations this week. Rallies were held in Sydney and Melbourne over the last two nights in support of Palestinians. The president of the Zionist Federation of Australi a, Jeremy Leibler, said some of the slogans being chanted at the Sydney demonstration were unacceptable. “I’m terrified when I see these marches through the city that are not holding candles and calling for peace as we see from rallies in the Jewish community when things have flared up in the Middle East,” he told ABC Radio Melbourne. “What we’re seeing is violent protests.” Mr Leibler said the response from Australian political leaders so far has been heartening. “I think we’ve had strong, very principled support – bipartisan support – both from the prime minister, from [opposition leader] Peter Dutton, and both at the state leadership levels as well,” he said. “So there should be. As there was after 9/11.” President of the Palestine Advocacy Network, Nasser Mashni, said he was disappointed by some of the language used at the pro-Palestinian demonstrations. “It’s entirely unacceptable. There is no room in our movement for antisemitism, any level of racism, Islamophobia, whatever,” he said. “Our struggle is an anti-colonial struggle for self-determination for all peoples in the holy land.” However, he said the move to project the Israeli flag on the Sydney Opera House was hurtful for Australians with a Palestinian background. “I’m Australian too, why don’t my children matter? When the [Sydney] Opera House is lit up in the Israeli flag there was an opportunity for Australia to have a moment of bringing together all peoples to say all children matter,” he said. “Both the flags could have been there.” Meanwhile, Victoria Police is investigating reports of antisemitic threats made in South Yarra yesterday. Police said the occupants of a car threatened a man on Toorak Road about 4pm yesterday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Entirely unacceptable': Australian Jewish, Palestinian communities condemn anti-Semitic chants

children.content: Reporting by
Tim Callanan
Representatives of the Australian Jewish and Palestinian communities have condemned anti-Semitic chants reported to have been shouted at pro-Palestinian demonstrations this week.
Rallies were held in Sydney and Melbourne over the last two nights in support of Palestinians.
The president of the
Zionist Federation of Australi
a, Jeremy Leibler, said some of the slogans being chanted at the Sydney demonstration were unacceptable.

“I’m terrified when I see these marches through the city that are not holding candles and calling for peace as we see from rallies in the Jewish community when things have flared up in the Middle East,” he told ABC Radio Melbourne.
“What we’re seeing is violent protests.”
Mr Leibler said the response from Australian political leaders so far has been heartening.

“I think we’ve had strong, very principled support – bipartisan support – both from the prime minister, from [opposition leader] Peter Dutton, and both at the state leadership levels as well,” he said.
“So there should be. As there was after 9/11.”
The demonstration at Sydney Opera House on Monday night.
(AAP: Dean Lewis)
President of the
Palestine Advocacy Network
, Nasser Mashni, said he was disappointed by some of the language used at the pro-Palestinian demonstrations.
“It’s entirely unacceptable. There is no room in our movement for antisemitism, any level of racism, Islamophobia, whatever,” he said.
“Our struggle is an anti-colonial struggle for self-determination for all peoples in the holy land.”
However, he said the move to project the Israeli flag on the Sydney Opera House was hurtful for Australians with a Palestinian background.

“I’m Australian too, why don’t my children matter? When the [Sydney] Opera House is lit up in the Israeli flag there was an opportunity for Australia to have a moment of bringing together all peoples to say all children matter,” he said.
“Both the flags could have been there.”
Meanwhile,
Victoria Police
is investigating reports of antisemitic threats made in South Yarra yesterday.
Police said the occupants of a car threatened a man on Toorak Road about 4pm yesterday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Jake Evans The Australian Jewry Council has confirmed an Australian grandmother was killed in the attack launched by Hamas. In a statement, the council's co-CEO Alex Ryvchin said the community was devastated to learn of the woman's death. "The Australian Jewish community is already devastated and confirmation of an Australian grandmother murdered in her home brings us new pain and sorrow," Mr Ryvchin said. "We mourn with the Carbone family at this terrible time and stand with the people of Israel and all the nations affected by this mass atrocity." Several media outlets have reported the woman killed was 66-year-old Galit Carbone, who was born in Sydney and moved to Israel as a teenager.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian grandmother killed in Israel

featuredLink.title: Australian grandmother confirmed killed in Israel

children.content: Reporting by Jake Evans
The
Australian Jewry Council
has confirmed an Australian grandmother was killed in the attack launched by Hamas.
In a statement, the council's co-CEO Alex Ryvchin said the community was devastated to learn of the woman's death.
"The Australian Jewish community is already devastated and confirmation of an Australian grandmother murdered in her home brings us new pain and sorrow," Mr Ryvchin said.
"We mourn with the Carbone family at this terrible time and stand with the people of Israel and all the nations affected by this mass atrocity."
Several media outlets have reported the woman killed was 66-year-old
Galit Carbone
, who was born in Sydney and moved to Israel as a teenager.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Fears are growing that the conflict could expand beyond Gaza, with Israel also facing wider threats and shared hostility from other non-state actors. Nicholas Blanford, a non-resident senior fellow with the Atlantic Council's Middle East Programs, told ABC News Radio Hezbollah was a very real and formidable threat to Israel. "It's a very close ally of the Hamas movement, so what is going in Gaza now has a direct impact on Hezbollah," he said. While the two groups are different the two share many similarities especially when it comes to shared hostility towards Israel. "In fact, the unprecedented operation Hamas conducted on Saturday breaking out of the Gaza, and entering the Israeli settlements around Gaza was straight out of Hezbollah's playbook," he said speaking from Beirut. "A massive rocket barrage, infiltration on mass across the border to cause as much damage and chaos as possible inside Israel. "Hezbollah have been training since 2007 but in this case it was Hamas which put it into practice with deadly effect." But he noted Hezbollah faced constraints with shots still being called by Iran, so if the group was told to go to all-out war with Israel they would. But he also said he wasn’t certain Hezbollah would want to face an all-out conflict knowing it would erode its “potent capabilities” further down the road. You can listen to News Radio live and more coverage of the conflict at the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas attack was 'right out of Hezbollah's playbook'

children.content: Fears are growing that the conflict could expand beyond Gaza, with Israel also facing wider threats and shared hostility from other non-state actors.
Nicholas Blanford,
a non-resident senior fellow with the Atlantic Council's Middle East Programs, told ABC News Radio
Hezbollah
was a very real and formidable threat to Israel.
"It's a very close ally of the Hamas movement,
so what is going in Gaza now has a direct impact on Hezbollah," he said.
While the two groups are different the two share many similarities especially when it comes to shared hostility towards Israel.

"In fact, the unprecedented operation Hamas conducted on Saturday breaking out of the Gaza, and entering the Israeli settlements around Gaza was straight out of Hezbollah's playbook," he said speaking from Beirut.
"A massive rocket barrage, infiltration on mass across the border to cause as much damage and chaos as possible inside Israel.
"Hezbollah have been training since 2007 but in this case it was Hamas which put it into practice with deadly effect."
But he noted Hezbollah faced constraints with shots still being called by Iran, so if the group was told to go to all-out war with Israel they would.
But he also said he wasn’t certain Hezbollah would want to face an all-out conflict knowing it would erode its “potent capabilities” further down the road.
You can listen to News Radio live and more coverage of the conflict at the link below.

image.altText: Thunderbirds players stand on the podium as pink streamers fill the air

items.synopsis: As netballers approach a second week without pay, negotiations between Netball Australia and the Australian Netball Players' Association reach a stalemate. So, what are they arguing about?

title.children: Netball's pay dispute boils down to a lack of trust

image.altText: a outback shelter with cars and charging and solar panels

items.synopsis: There are not many electric car chargers along one of Australia's longest roads, but one local company has developed a prototype it hopes will help range anxiety in the outback.

title.children: 'It's very novel': Could this portable charger with solar panels solve range anxiety in the outback?

image.altText: Mohammad Rizwan raises his bat and helmet during a Cricket World Cup match.

items.synopsis: Ireland's time at the top of the World Cup record books is over after Pakistan eclipsed a 12-year-old mark for the highest run chase in World Cup history, notching 4-345 to take down Sri Lanka.

title.children: Pakistan breaks World Cup record with mammoth chase, while Stokes misses another England clash

image.altText: A man in a green shirt riding a white pony on a sandy field. He's leaning off the pony and placing a ring on an orange cone.

items.synopsis: Acrobatic dismounts, dramatic handovers and furious galloping are common in this niche sport, which is being played regional Victoria right now as part of a world championship event.

title.children: This equestrian sport for 'adrenaline junkies' involves balloons, socks and tennis balls

image.altText: Afghan men carry on their shoulders the body of a woman earthquake victim, wrapped in black cloth.

items.synopsis: As the search for survivors ends, relief efforts are underway and in an area of Afghanistan that was badly hit in an earthquake earlier this year, even beggars are donating what they can to help.

title.children: Afghanistan pleads for help after deadly earthquake reduced villages to rubble and dust

image.altText: A side by side image of a father dressed in a hat and a son dressed in a suit

items.synopsis: Air crash investigators examining the light plane crash that claimed the lives of SA men Ben and Charlie Mumford say initial evidence corroborates reports the aircraft hit a powerline while attempting to land.

title.children: Plane crash that killed father and son caused by powerline strike, early ATSB evidence suggests

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: Brahman with skin blemish

items.synopsis: Large numbers of healthy cattle are being rejected from Australia's live export trade to Indonesia due to skin blemishes. Producers say there's no alternative market and are calling on government to act.

title.children: Cosmetic skin blemishes on this Brahman mean it can't be exported to Indonesia. Why?

image.altText: Israeli soldiers carry the body of a victim of an attack by militants from Gaza .

items.synopsis: Israeli soldiers begin the grim work of collecting the bodies of those killed in Hamas' terror attack as rockets continue to fly overhead.

title.children: Killed 'in their beds and protection rooms': Inside Kfar Aza kibbutz after Hamas terrorists attacked

image.altText: A grey background with a photo of a hand putting a piece of paper in a ballot box, question marks surround.

items.synopsis: On Saturday, millions will go to the polls to cast their votes on changing the Australian constitution to establish Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice. Catch up on the basics to get yourself ready to vote.

title.children: What is the Voice to Parliament? Your most common questions answered in 150 words or less

image.altText: A large crowd gathered outside the Opera House

items.synopsis: Backlash following this week's move to light-up the Sydney Opera House in the colours of the Israeli flag is not the first time the iconic landmark has been caught up in political debate.

title.children: A look back at the most politically controversial moments the Sydney Opera House was lit-up

image.altText: Student wearing school uniform places mobile phone into yondr pouch

items.synopsis: Kotara High School principal Mark Sneddon says the "battle with phones in class is gone" and student habits are changing at home.

title.children: Noise from the playground got louder when phones were banned. So what else happened?

image.altText: Destroyed buildings in Rimal, Gaza.

items.synopsis: As attacks from both sides escalate and the death toll rises, there are fears people will be trapped in Gaza with no humanitarian corridor after further air strikes leave neighbourhoods reduced to rubble.

title.children: Israel destroys whole Gaza neighbourhoods as defence minister tells his forces offensive will 'intensify'

image.altText: Close up shot of a woman's hands clasped on a lap

items.synopsis: Historic legislation is set to be introduced in Queensland today, with Hannah Clarke's parents praising the new protection for victims.

title.children: Lucy followed her husband's directions in hopes he'd love her more, until she realised she was being coercively controlled

image.altText: A young woman wearing sunglasses looks out a car window

items.synopsis: Tasmania's public housing overcrowding rates are higher than the national average and continue to grow, with one family in Hobart's northern suburbs given priority status still waiting after four years.

title.children: Katlyn's been told she can't get a bigger house for her growing family, so she drives around looking for one

image.altText: A young woman with dark skin and black hair wearing yellow headphones looks at a yellow smartphone

items.synopsis: While some are optimistic about the streaming giant's move into audiobooks, others fear it will threaten authors' already precarious livelihoods.

title.children: Authors fear Spotify's move into audiobooks risks 'killing the golden goose'

image.altText: A soldier in military uniform and holding a gun stands in front of a destroyed apartment building with emergency crews.

items.synopsis: To prepare their soldiers for the psychological challenges of combat, the Ukrainian military has developed a sophisticated resilience training program. Its insights may be very valuable to other militaries — including the ADF, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Inside the Ukrainian military's resilience training, where soldiers' mental strength is a weapon

image.altText: Silhouette of a man standing on a shoreline at sunset looking out at an oil rig on the ocean.

items.synopsis: It could take hundreds of years — if not thousands — to reverse decline to ocean fish habitat if warming's not kept below climate targets, according to new research.

title.children: A 'double whammy' for fish — and humans — if climate targets are overshot

image.altText: A low shot looking up at a sign on the side of Perth Children's Hospital.

items.synopsis: A new report reveals there were four serious sexual safety incidents reported by children and young people receiving mental healthcare in WA in the last financial year. It follows shocking allegations of a teenager being raped by a fellow patient at Perth Children's Hospital.

title.children: New report reveals number of 'sexual safety incidents' involving children in wake of alleged PCH rape

image.altText: A simple wooden cross in the ground at an outback cemetery.

items.synopsis: Advocates say access to mental health services needs to be urgently improved after an ABS report reveals an increase in tragedy all too common in First Nations communities.

title.children: 'It's in your face': Shocking figures reveal leading cause of death for Indigenous children

image.altText: Mustafa Barghouti

items.synopsis: A Palestinian political leader says terrorist group Hamas is ready to free civilian hostages if Israel accepts an immediate ceasefire, claiming the militants have agreed not to carry out executions.

title.children: Palestinian politician claims Hamas ready to swap hostages
